top_comment.text:
*Cornell West vs Obama*

Dr. Cornel West says that President Barack Obama doesn't deserve to be 
sworn in for his second term as President of the United States with his 
hand on the bible of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

"You don't play with Martin Luther King, Jr. and you don't play with his 
people, by his people, I mean people of good conscience, fundamentally 
committed to peace and truth and justice".﻿

him like a god......Cornell West and Cenk Uygur share a trait though: They

PS - The look on Newt Gingrich's face in the background while Brother

PPS- Does Cornell West have a problem with his neck here? Add his missing

top_comment.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:
mike58greenberg, why you are going back to this after a long hiatus escapes 
me. Something tells me you are a devotee of Howard Zinn, or Noam Chomsky, 
or both. Such are the those who not only have a flaming hatred for this 
country, but a righteous indignation tinged with an unrestrained arrogance 
towards those who do not share their worldview. Noone said that 
geopolitical history is not complicated. The two academics cited, however, 
have such a one-sided anti-American view on pretty much anything that 
happens, that no serious individual with anything resembling a balanced 
view of things can take them seriously. I can imagine those two somewhat 
hysterical "historians" meeting; Zinn sneezes and Chomsky declares it a 
result of another American atrocity, his favorite saying.

Learn balance, mike. Lose the arrogance. Read both sides. It is telling 
that your idea of a conservative is Sarah Palin. Palin is an idiot; who 
cares about her? Go read Thomas Sowell for some balance. Try out Milton 
Friedman, William F. Buckley, and perhaps George Will as well. 

I never claimed the United States was or is perfect. Among other things, 
the bureacracy is now such that little will run efficiently. Bad things 
have been done by those representing this country, including by generals in 
war; that doesn't make this country bad as a whole.

Overall, the US remains a force for good in the world, despite the current 
president of the United States who I suspect quietly shares your worldview.

And nothing changes the fact that Martin Luther King Jr. was not a god, but 
a deeply flawed human being, despite this video and many in the popular 
culture depicting him as the former.
comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo Nowhere did I deny, nor put forth, that MLK was a 
communist. As for him not being a god... "We are all cracked vessels... 
We're just trying to love our crooked neighbors with our crooked hearts"
That quote should sound familiar to you, being a history teacher.
I appreciate your concern about 'hatred' in my heart. It's more like 
righteous indignation, anger over injustices toward these, the least of our 
brethren.
The cheap shot as Sarah Palin does not reflect hatred in my heart-- I was 
actually thinking of the way she made the comparison of waterboarding (a 
form of torture) to communion (a sacred ritual in certain denominations of 
Christianity) which certainly seems to indicate hate, or a lack of empathy, 
or at least manners.
Now, not being familiar with, or not curious about, Cointelpro is testament 
to our disinterest in history and our incapacity to be concerned citizens. 
To be sure, USA is a force for good for the most part. But to deny that the 
CIA plays a significant, and often destructive, role in the geopolitical 
power sphere, is naïve.
I love my country, which is exactly why I exercise my right to speak out 
against injustices. Evelyn Beatrice Hall once wrote, "I disapprove of what 
you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it" (no, it 
wasn't Voltaire that said that)...
comments.author: mike58greenberg

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo well, you may be right in that it certainly sounds 
anti-american, but maybe it's just MLK's way of saying that we need to 
change our ways, like stop using WMDs (like cluster bombs, napalm and 
depleted uranium).
Now, I am a true patriot, as witnessed by the fact that I care for the 
Constitution and the Bill of Rights. I care deeply for our national parks. 
I care deeply for the well-being of our fellow citizens and think that it 
is unfortunate when families are not allowed to thrive for any reason. I 
think it is wrong when individuals wrongfully take possession of others' 
property. I am proud of the good things this country stands for. The 
founding fathers, many of them, were well-educated men, many of them 
lawyers, certainly all of them familiar with the Magna Carta. They believed 
in freedom of religion, which is why it is inaccurate to say that this is a 
Christian nation. It is a nation that will not meddle in such private 
affairs as our faith. You should know this. 
Again, read up on your history. It's our military contractors and 
sub-contractors that are commiting the war crimes...
1. I'm sure you know about Operation Paperclip. Some of them ended up in our
military industry. Learn some history, dude.
2. Check out Phil Tourney, telling about the USS Liberty and Operation 
Cyanide. 
3. Learn about Cointelpro, and the burglary that led to it. Those involved 
were truly american heroes, I'm sure you can name at least one of them.
4. Learn about Agent Orange.
5. Learn about cluster bombs and what they do to human flesh. Tell me that 
you think that it somehow is not morally reprehensible.
Listen to Mark Regev, spouting lies, and Miko Peled, telling the truth.
Listen to Dick Cheney, supporting things that are against the constitution.
Check out Ann Coulter, spouting lies, and Glen Greenwald, telling the 
truth. Challenge your system of beliefs. 
Be prepared for the cognitive dissonance, man. It's inevitable.
comments.author: mike58greenberg

comments.text: Smh.
comments.author: Avi Gindratt

comments.text:
Sorry, Avi Gindratt, communism is an evil system. While there have been 
times that people have fallen in love with the idea, they have not thought 
the consequences through. Not allowing people to keep the fruits of their 
labor is morally wrong.

Liberal teachers, especially professors, are infamous for inserting their 
political biases into their lessons, as well as unfairly grading down 
papers whose political theory is not one they agree with.

As for me, I bent over so far backwards to teach history down the middle 
that virtually all of my students (JHS) assumed I was a liberal! Which I am 
not. But I was very focused on teaching properly. If any political question 
arose, I would respond by giving the students both sides of the issue. 

I no longer teach history - I now teach HS math. On my last day of teaching 
history I told my last class that I am in fact a Republican/Conservative. 
Not what they expected.
comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo With overly patriotic, nationalistic teachers such as 
yourself, given your rhetoric here, it is no surprise that folks have such 
ahistorical, biased, and uncritical analyses of present day politics.

I have no problem, either, with the fact that "MLK was not a god." He 
wasn't. I didn't read the other folks' comments, but I never defended MLK's 
deification, if that's even a thing; I said that if folks view him as such, 
it is rather irrelevant. He was instead a great man (if that's the 
perspective you're criticizing), an activist--someone to whom I owe much 
for my privilege in this great country; someone that petty right-wingers 
consistently trivialize, and whose critique of US foreign policy exposes 
the bitter hypocrisy of being the most violent nation on Earth while 
criticizing the relatively marginal violence of other cultures. Yet, I'm 
the "uninformed" one.

Likewise, I stand by the claim that being a communist is not altogether 
bad. I mean, surely a teacher, if anybody, should know that every ideology 
throughout history has had its de facto benefits and pitfalls, despite its 
normative definition. C'mon now.
comments.author: Avi Gindratt

comments.text:
Oh, gee. I dare say that MLK Jr. was a human and not a god, and here comes 
the Traveling, Liberal, Hate America First Olympics. Our 
contestants.....(drumroll, please) #1. Avi Gindratt! #2. Lauren Caldwell! 
#3. Mike58greenberg!
Lord help us all.
You people have gone way too far. Glad you decided I'm an ignorant racist. 
Fools, all of you. 
As a former US history teacher, I find it amusing to get lectured about 
history by the biased and/or uninformed such as yourselves. Despite the 
fact that Aug 28, 1963, was well before I was born, it is a date I know 
well (no Googling necessary). For those of you three who don't know, that 
would be the date of the March on Washington, where MLK Jr. gave his I Have 
a Dream speech, parts of which I played to my sons when they were too young 
to appreciate it. It was a brilliant and moving speech. But it still 
doesn't make MLK Jr. into a god. Sorry. 
Avi Gindratt is the most baffled of the three of you. Avi, your ignorance 
is breathtaking. I particularly like how Avi says there is nothing wring 
with the fact that MLK was a communist, while Mike insisist that MLK wasn't 
a communist. Get on the same page, folks. While I am not a particularly 
strong Sarah Palin fan, your shot at her, Mike, was gratuitous, and reveals 
the hatred in your heart. All three of you should be able to handle the 
breaking news that MLK was not a god without falling to pieces. And one 
more thing: Any of you who does not understand that the USA is a force for 
good in this world is totally lost.

Cheers.
comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:
Vincent Cuttolo: You're sounding like Sarah Palin here. 1. He used 
citations in his speeches, to be sure. 2. You have never heard of the 
Cointelpro?? They harassed and slandered him viciously, as they did the 
National Guild of Lawyers, non-violent Civil Rights activists and various 
student organizations who protested the Vietnam War. 3. He was interested 
in implementing social programs to make for a more equitable distribution 
of wealth. That's not communism. 4. He was vehemently against the Vietnam 
War. That's not Anti-American, you twerp.  Get your facts straight, for 
chrissakes. And learn some history, please. You are so embarrassing.
comments.author: mike58greenberg

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo Like I said YOU my friend are a troll. You can criticize 
MLK but to act like highlighting his shortcomings ( bc he was a human 
being) takes away from what he did and what he meant to a whole population 
of minorities in this country is ridiculous. You are a troll bc u take 
pride in being ignorant and sharing your ignorance behind a veil on social 
media.
comments.author: lauren caldwell

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo "a few thousand poor, broke settlers came here and managed 
to wipe out a quarter of the world's population"--As a matter of fact, yes. 
But like I said, I was "being nice," and the figure I was using of 100 
million, to your point, is the highest, and highly improbable, estimate. 
However, why are we ignoring the fact that America can nevertheless be 
compared to Stalin and Hitler in that they commit mass genocides? lol. 

In any case, you're missing the point and changing the subject: the US is 
the biggest warmonger on planet Earth. As such, it is the biggest threat to 
peace the world has ever known.

Furthermore, to berate MLK's personal life is what we'd expect a petty, 
white racist, reactionist, anti-humanitarian, neo-con warmonger to do in an 
attempt to undermine one of the greatest civil rights leaders in world 
history. The critical perspective here is not whether or not he had 
mistresses or was a communist (which is not a bad thing), or whether people 
deifying him is appropriate; those are all reasonable conclusions. It is 
instead whether or not his analyses can be effectively applied today.
comments.author: Avi Gindratt

comments.text:
lauren caldwell, you did not address your comment to anyone specific, but 
it seems likely you were talking to me. I hope that we are not at the point 
where any legitimate criticism of MLK Jr. is so unacceptable that anyone 
who points out the truth is assumed to be a troll. 
Avi Gindratt, it is stunning that you are not embarassed to publicize your 
ignorance so clearly. 100 million Native Americans? That's a joke, right? 
Leaving aside the moral question of what exactly took place between 
settlers in the new world and Native Americans back when (and it is far 
from a simple, one-sided picture), let me know when you can find a single 
reputable source anywhere that shows that 100 thousand Native Americans 
were killed, let alone 100 million. The entire world population back then 
was a few hundred million. So, a few thousand poor, broke settlers came 
here and managed to wipe out a quarter of the world's population?
comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo "Common sense" doesn't constitute fact. My point stands: 
Americans have no right to criticize injustice if they can't even address 
the extent to which their own country engages in it. 

Why the reluctance to view America as one of the most violent nations ever? 
Is it because we're not as violent as I'm suggesting, or is it because 
you're an American who can't stand looking in the mirror and seeing the 
very thing you claim to abhor? I'd say it's the latter. For example, Hitler 
and Stalin killed, what, like, 50-60 million people together? America 
killed 50-60 million Native Americans alone (and that's being nice; it is 
actually about 100million, considering diseases n shit). Hitler had a long 
way to go to get to America's violence, as did Stalin. Same goes for your 
other convenient deflections.
comments.author: Avi Gindratt

comments.text: Troll
comments.author: lauren caldwell

comments.text:
Avi Gindratt, you are very ignorant. A quote I like: Facts are stubborn

more wrong than you are on statements of fact.
comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:

comments.author: Avi Gindratt

comments.text:

·Hitler

That's a start. I can give you more. Your statement about the US killing

comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:
+Vincent Cuttolo I do live in the US, yes, and voicing reasonable criticism 
of our beloved republic is not reason that I should leave; it is actually 
evidence of me doing my job as a free citizen. And although I'm not exactly 
"angry," I do rather resent the idea that I should leave my own country 
because it promotes a culture of racism and self-righteous indignation 
against critical voices. That almost seems fascist of you to suggest. 

The answer you probably wont give to my question, "What entity, ever, is 
responsible for as much violence as the United States?" is: no country 
ever. This fact, or "truth," as I put it, has heavy implications on your 
exasperated sense nationalism is all I'm saying.
comments.author: Avi Gindratt

comments.text:
Avi Gindratt, you seem really angry. Do you live in the US? Why not move in 
with all those lovers of peace in Iran? And Syria? The US is a force for 
good in the world, and sorry for you if you don't get that.
comments.author: Vincent Cuttolo

comments.text:

comments.text:
Dr. West reminds us what MLK stood for and how he is presuming that MLK 
would not have agreed with the President's choice's and current political 
situations in our society and around the world. It is not about the fact

being judged, his actions, not just the words of the Oath.  Dr. West feels 
that his actions would not be condoned by MLK and rightly so...

My personal opinion, it is 50% 50% Obama, while not perfect, not a man that 
worked with the church...but with the Law : ) to gravely different things. 
 Obama has made great strides and fought for the people in many 
instances...but played lawyer and lost too many times...i.e. BANKS- He has 
risked his life to be our leader, and the first African American President. 
He is owed some respect and I am hoping that he stops playing lawyer and 
embraces the legacy he swore his oath on.

comments.text:
+moonrice555    True. To be honest, I'm a bit guilty of it also. The first 
times I posted things, I got some amazing rough feedback, so it seemed like 
that was what YouTube was about.  It's taken a while before I've had 
contact with people who demonstrated that decent conversations could be 
had. It's told me a few things about myself. I've said a few things to 
people here that I would never dream of saying in real life. But the longer 
I've been on, I've received more intelligent interactions, so it's become 
much more promising than it was to begin with.

I have the feeling that it's mostly children and drunks, so it takes awhile 
to find people who are truly interested in debate and exchange.
comments.author: Ed Bzoky

comments.text:
+Ed Bzoky I see. And it is refreshing to talk about this stuff online with 
someone without being called an "idiot" or "dumbass". The fact that you 
spoke to me like I'm a human being made me more willing to listen to you 
and I wish to god more people would see that. Most of what I see is just 
people tearing into each other and zero progress is made.
comments.author: moonrice555

comments.text:

they need to know by watching 17 minutes of nightly news is very

But it still appears to me that Cornel West is not into critical thinking

comments.text:
The reason why other professors don't do it and don't choose to do it is 
that they CAN'T do it. They have to work. West always demands jobs and 
positions that don't require him to teach, or require him to teach very 
little. University Professorships, etc. That gives him time to go out and 
rap, intimate how classy he is -- "I have a suit made in London," "We'll 
have to discuss this over cognac" surprising talk from the man of the 
people -- and so on. He will not take a job where he cannot set his own 
hours, teach what he wants, be forced to publish, Yes, I do know this. 

I've seen many speeches by him, and the most remarkable thing is that in 
all those videos, I have never seen him -NOT ONCE - indicate ANY kind of 
interest in the views of others, NEVER seen any indication of curiousity at 
all about what others might think. Check it out. 

People don't need to be told by him that Obama is not as progressive as 
they thought. Even people like Matt Damon know this.
comments.author: Ed Bzoky

comments.text:
+Ed Bzoky "WHY does he think he is so much above other professors, who have 
to teach, grade papers, and work for their living, while he just gives 
talks?"  What? He chooses to go out there and make speeches, to write books 
about social problems, to talk on the radio, tv. If the other professors 
wanted to do that---who is stopping them? As far as establishment 
politicians, other leaders went against the grain---why is it wrong for him 
to point out that Obama could have done the same and didn't? He's just 
showing all the people in their trance that Obama isn;t as progressive as 
they think.
comments.author: moonrice555

comments.text:
How is it verifiable to say that Obama does not care about poor people? 
Obama is a politician, a Democratic politician. Is West stupid? Does he 
think that an establishment politician is going to turn non-establishment 
because he's black? Did he really think that Obama could or would do 
something different than any other politician? I'm not an Obama fan, but it 
looks to me like West just chose the biggest target he could in order to 
get some notoriety for himself. That -- notoriety -- is his biggest and 
probably only goal. 

WHY does he think he is so much above other professors, who have to teach, 
grade papers, and work for their living, while he just gives talks? (Or 
preaches, as he would claim.) What on earth has he done that is any more or 
better than what so many other professors do? What evidence is there -- 
really -- that he is particularly smart?
comments.author: Ed Bzoky
